Question 1.Question: Which of the following is the foremost right of a citizen?

Question 10.Question: A type of constitution that is difficult to amend is described as
Question 10.Explanation: Constitutions are classified into rigid and flexible. A rigid Constitution is one that requires a special procedure for its amendment, e.g. the American constitution. Question 11.Explanation: Maintaining international peace and security are achievements of the UN. Question 12.Question: Elective principle in Nigeria was first introduced by
Question 12.Explanation: Sir Hugh Clifford was appointed Governor of Nigeria after Lord Fredrick Lugard. In 1922, Sir Clifford introduced the first formal constitution for the country. The main feature of the constitution was the introduction of the elective principle in Nigeria.

Question 13.Question: The three major political parties of the first republic could be said to have had
Question 13.Explanation: By the first republic, Nigeria was split into three geopolitical regions — Western, Eastern and Northern Region — and its political parties took on the identities and ideologies of each region. The Nigerian People's Congress (NPC) represented the interests of the Hausa/Fulani Northern Region, the National Council of Nigeria and the Cameroons (NCNC)] (later renamed to "National Council of Nigerian Citizens") represented the Igbo Eastern Region, and the Action Group (AG) dominated the Yoruba Western Region.

Question 19.Question: The Ombudsman aims at
Question 19.Explanation: In Nigeria, the Ombudsman is known as the Public Complaints Commission. The machinery is meant for the control of administrative excesses or injustices at federal, state and local Government levels. It is an organ of the government set up to redress complaints lodged by aggrieved citizens or residents in Nigeria against administrative injustice.

Question 20.Question: The apex body under the military regime of Yakubu Gowon was
Question 20.Explanation: The Supreme Military Council was the body that ruled Nigeria after the 1966 coup d'état until it was dissolved following the 1979 parliamentary election and the Second Nigerian Republic. According to a Constitutional Decree, published in Lagos on 17 March 1967, legislative and executive power was vested in the Supreme Military Council. The Chairman of the Council was the head of the Military Government. The initial President of the Supreme Military Council was General Yakubu Gowon, Commander-in-Chief of the Nigerian Armed Forces but was replaced by Muritala Muhammed (in 1975) and Olusegun Obasanjo (in 1976) in successive coups.
